standard_metadata.standard_description: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.

question.content: The school board administered a reading test to all eighth-grade students at High Achievers Charter School and determined that $10\%$ of them were reading below grade level.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $10\%$ of all students at HACS are reading below grade level.
$10\%$ of all eighth-grade students at HACS are reading below grade level.
$10\%$ of students in this sample are reading below grade level, but we cannot conclude anything about the eighth-grade students at HACS.

hints.content: *All* students in the eighth grade at HACS were tested, so we can make the valid conclusion that $10\%$ of all eighth-grade students at HACS are reading below grade level.
However, we don't know if the eighth-grade students are representative of all students at HACS, so we can't draw conclusions about that population from this data.
**The valid conclusion:**  **$10\%$ of all eighth-grade students at HACS are reading below grade level.**

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: The school board administered a math test to all students in grade $6$ at High Achievers Charter School and determined that $15\%$ of them were  below grade level in math.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $15\%$ of all students at HACS are  below grade level in math.
$15\%$ of all  students in grade $6$ at HACS are below grade level in math.
$15\%$ of students in the sample are below grade level in math, but we cannot conclude anything about the students in grade $6$ at HACS.

hints.content: *All* students in the grade $6$ at HACS were tested, so we can make the valid conclusion that $15\%$ of all students in grade $6$ at HACS are below grade level in math.
However, we don't know about all students at HACS. We can't draw conclusions about this population.
**The valid conclusion:**  **$15\%$ of all  students in grade $6$ at HACS are below grade level in math.**

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: Tasty Treats Baking Company asked all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High School the question, “Do you prefer chocolate or butterscotch Tasty Treats?”  Everyone surveyed had to pick one of the two answers, and $42\%$ said they preferred chocolate.    **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $42\%$ of all students at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.
$42\%$ of all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.
$42\%$ of the male students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

hints.content: *All* students in the senior class were surveyed, so we can make the valid conclusion that $42\%$ of all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.

However, we don't know if the senior class is representative of all students at Ridgemont or of all the males in the senior class, so we can't draw conclusions about those populations from this survey.
**The valid conclusion:**  **$42\%$ of all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.**

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: Wholesome Food Company asked all students on the baseball team at Ridgemont High School the question, “Do you like broccoli?” and $15\%$ answered “Yes.”    **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $15\%$ of all students on the baseball team at Ridgemont High like broccoli.
$15\%$ of all students at Ridgemont High like broccoli.
$15\%$ of the outfielders on the baseball team like broccoli, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

hints.content: *All* students on the baseball team were surveyed, so we can make the valid conclusion that $15\%$ of all students on the baseball team at Ridgemont High like broccoli.

However, we don't know if the baseball team is representative of all students at Ridgemont or of specifically the outfielders on the baseball team, so we can't draw conclusions about those populations from this survey.
**The valid conclusion:**  **$15\%$ of all students on the baseball team at Ridgemont High like broccoli.**

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: Lincoln Junior High School asked all of their eighth grade students the question, “What is your favorite breakfast?” and $18\%$ answered “pancakes.”    **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $18\%$ of all students in the eighth grade at Lincoln Junior High School have breakfast as their favorite meal.
$18\%$ of all students at Lincoln Junior High School have breakfast as their favorite meal.

$18\%$ of all students in the eighth grade at Lincoln Junior High School have pancakes as their favorite breakfast, but we cannot conclude anything about the percent of the population who have breakfast as their favorite meal.

hints.content: *All* students in the eighth grade were surveyed, so we can make the valid conclusion that $18\%$ of all students in the eighth grade at Lincoln Junior High School have pancakes as their favorite breakfast.
However, the question did not ask about the students' favorite meal of the day, so we cannot draw any valid conclusions about the students' favorite meal.

The valid conclusion:  $18\%$ of all students in the eighth grade at Lincoln Junior High School have pancakes as their favorite breakfast, but we cannot conclude anything about the percent of the population who have breakfast as their favorite meal.

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: The Adventure Zone amusement park asked all of their employees who attend college how many hours of homework they had per week and determined that they had an average of $24$ hours of homework per week.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $24\%$ of all of the amusement park employees who attend college have homework each week.
$24\%$ of all of the amusement park employees who attend school have homework each week.
The amusement park employees who attend college have an average of $24$ hours of homework per week, but we cannot conclude anything about the percent of the population who have homework.

hints.content: *All* of the amusement park employees who attend college were surveyed, so we can make the valid conclusion that the amusement park employees who attend college have an average of $24$ hours of homework per week.
However, we only know the average number of hours, not how many of the employees had homework, so we cannot draw any valid conclusions about the percent of the population who have homework.

The valid conclusion:  The amusement park employees who attend college have an average of $24$ hours of homework per week, but we cannot conclude anything about the percent of the population who have homework.

item.problemType: Which all

question.content: A large random sample of American students in seventh grade showed that $20\%$ of them were reading below grade level.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: About $20\%$ of all American students in seventh grade were reading below grade level.
$20\%$ of this sample was reading below grade level, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.
About $20\%$ of all American students were reading below grade level.

hints.content: A large random sample of American students in the seventh grade gives valid information about the population of all American seventh graders.
This sample may not be representative of all American students.
**The valid conclusion:**  **About $20\%$ of all American students in seventh grade were reading below grade level.**

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: Tasty Treats Baking Company asked a random sample of $100$ students in the senior class at Ridgemont High School the question, “Do you prefer chocolate or butterscotch Tasty Treats?”  Everyone surveyed had to pick one of the two answers, and $42\%$ said they preferred chocolate.    **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: About $42\%$ of all students at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.
About $42\%$ of all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.
$42\%$ of this sample preferred chocolate, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

hints.content: A random sample of $100$ students in the senior class gives valid information about the population of all $100$ students in the senior class.
However, we don't know if the senior class is representative of all students at Ridgemont so we can't draw conclusions about that population from this survey.
**The valid conclusion:**  **About $42\%$ of all students in the senior class at Ridgemont High prefer chocolate.**

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: Good Taste Food Company asked $100$ randomly selected students at Ridgemont High School the question, “Do you prefer pizza or a veggie burger for lunch?” and $67\%$ answered “pizza.”    **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: About $67\%$ of all students at Ridgemont High prefer pizza for lunch.
$67\%$ of the students in the sample prefer pizza for lunch, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.
About $67\%$ of all teenagers prefer pizza for lunch.

hints.content: A large random sample of students at Ridgemont High School gives valid information about the population of all students at that school.
This sample may not be representative of all teenagers.
**The valid conclusion:**  **About $67\%$ of all students at Ridgemont High prefer pizza for lunch.**

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: Sweet Treats candy company wants to introduce a new flavor of jelly bean.  They have three choices: Mango, Papaya, or Coconut.  They decide to do a survey to determine which flavor their customers prefer.  A random sample of $100$ Sweet Treats customers tried a free sample of all three flavors.  The data showed that $55\%$ preferred Mango, $20\%$ preferred Papaya, and $25\%$ preferred Coconut.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $55\%$ of customers in this sample prefer Mango, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.
About $55\%$ of all Sweet Treats customers prefer Mango.
About $55\%$ of all adults prefer mango.

hints.content: A large random sample of Sweet Treats customers gives valid information about the population of all Sweet Treats customers.
This sample may not be representative of all adults.
**The valid conclusion:**  ** About $55\%$ of all Sweet Treats customers prefer Mango.**

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: The Read and Feed restaurant wants to know how satisfied their customers are with their service. They printed an internet link to a survey on every receipt, and $150$ of their customers chose to answer the survey. The data showed that $60\%$ of the customers were satisfied with their service.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: $60\%$ of customers in this sample are satisfied, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.
About $60\%$ of all Read and Feed customers are satisfied.
About $60\%$ of all Read and Feed customers who have internet access are satisfied.

hints.content: A sample of customers who choose to fill out a satisfaction survey and who have internet access may have different opinions than those who do not or cannot fill out the survey. So the sample may not be representative of all customers.
The valid conclusion:  $60\%$ of customers in this sample are satisfied, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: When Jonas becomes the Receiver of Memory, he gets a rule that he may not tell his dreams. He wants to know how many of his $50$ classmates have the same rule. He asks $5$ friends from his class whether they may tell their dreams.  Of those, $4$ say that they may.   **Based on this data, which of the following conclusions are valid?**

options.content: About $80\%$ of all of Jonas's classmates may tell their dreams.
About $80\%$ of all people in Jonas's community may tell their dreams.
$80\%$ of the classmates in this sample may tell their dreams, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

hints.content: A group of Jonas's friends may not be representative of all of Jonas's classmates.
The valid conclusion:  $80\%$ of the classmates in this sample may tell their dreams, but we cannot conclude anything about the population.

item.problemType: Sample to pop?

question.content: City Councilwoman Kelly wants to know whether the residents of her district support a proposed school redistricting plan.       **Which of the following survey methods will allow Councilwoman Kelly to make a valid conclusion about whether residents of her district support  the proposed plan?**

options.content: Ask $200$ residents of her district whose names are chosen at random.
Ask $200$ parents at the local playground.

hints.content: Asking $200$ residents of her district whose names are chosen at random from her district  will produce information from which she can make a valid conclusion.
Parents at a playground may not represent the residents of her district.
**The valid method:**  **Ask $200$ residents of her district whose names are chosen at random.**

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Ross wants to conduct a survey of his $400$ classmates to determine which candidate for class treasurer, Warren or Willa,  is in the lead in the upcoming election.  Ross will ask the question, “If the election were today, which candidate would get your vote?”    **Which of the following methods of surveying his classmates will allow Ross to make  valid conclusions about which candidate is in the lead?**

options.content: Ask the $50$ students in his first and second period classes.
Put the names of all the students in a hat, and draw $50$ names.  Ask those students whose names are drawn.

hints.content: Putting names in a hat and drawing $50$ of them  will produce a random sample that will give him valid information about which candidate is in the lead.
The classmates in Ross's first and second period classes are not random samples. They may not represent the entire population of Ross's classmates.
**The valid method:**  **Put the names of all the students in a hat, and draw $50$ names.  Ask those students whose names are drawn.**

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: The curriculum committee at Larchmont High School wants to offer a new elective course next year.  They decide  to survey Larchmont's $1500$ students to determine which course students would prefer.  The choices are History of Art,  Robotics, and  Money and You.          **Which of the following survey methods will allow the committee to make a valid conclusion about which course the students at Larchmont prefer?**

options.content: Ask $150$ students in science classes which course they would prefer.
Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $150$ random numbers between $1$ and $1500$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.

hints.content: Selecting students whose numbers are randomly selected by a computer would produce a random sample, and the committee could make valid generalizations based on that data.
Science students are not a random sample. They may not represent the entire school.
**The valid method:**  **Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $150$ random numbers between $1$ and $1500$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.**

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: The entertainment committee at Maplecrest Junior High School has narrowed down the theme of the Spring Dance to three choices. The ten committee members want to conduct a survey to determine which theme Maplecrest's $2000$ students prefer. There will be three choices (Disco Fever, The Crazy Eighties, or Hip Hop Til You Drop) and the committee will go with the theme that gets the most votes.      **Which of the following survey methods will allow the committee  to make a valid conclusion about which theme Maplecrest's student body prefers?**

options.content: Each of the $10$ committee members can ask $10$ friends to obtain a sample of $100$ students.
Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $100$ random numbers between $1$ and $2000$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.

hints.content: Selecting students whose numbers are randomly selected by a computer would produce a random sample, and the committee could make valid generalizations based on that data.
Friends of the committee members  may not represent the broader Maplecrest population.
**The valid method:**  ** Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $100$ random numbers between $1$ and $2000$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.**

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Wholesome Food Company has been hired to design a healthy menu for the cafeteria at Ridgemont High School.  They want to conduct a survey to determine what percentage of Ridgemont’s $1500$ students like broccoli. The survey will ask, “Do you like broccoli?”      **Which of the following survey methods will allow Wholesome Food Company to make a valid conclusion about the percentage of students at Ridgemont that like broccoli?**

options.content: Ask $100$ students in line at the salad bar during lunchtime for one week.
Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $100$ different random numbers between $1$ and $1500$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.

hints.content: Selecting students whose numbers are randomly selected by a computer would produce a random sample, and the company could make valid generalizations based on that data.
The other method would not provide random samples of the student population. Students in line for the salad bar may not represent the broader Ridgemont population.

**The valid method:**  **Assign a number to each student, and use a computer program to generate $100$ different random numbers between $1$ and $1500$.  Ask those students whose numbers are selected.**

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Bella wants to conduct a survey to determine how many of the residents of Forks believe in supernatural creatures.      **Which of the following survey methods will allow Bella to make a valid conclusion about the percentage of residents of Forks that believe in supernatural creatures?**

options.content: Ask a randomly selected sample of residents to answer the question anonymously.
Ask a randomly selected sample of high school students to answer the question anonymously.

hints.content: Both groups are random samples, so Bella could generalize the results from each sample to the population from which they came.  Which population is Bella interested in?
Bella wants to draw a conclusion about the residents of Forks, not about the students at the high school.
The valid method:  Ask a randomly selected sample of residents to answer the question anonymously.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Santos wants to know what percentage of people who get married in his county knew each other in school.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow Santos to make a valid conclusion about the percentage of couples married in his county who knew each other in school?**

options.content: Get a list of the $30$ couples most recently married in his county, then ask them.
Sort a list of couples married in his county into a random order, then ask the first $30$ couples on the list.

hints.content: Asking $30$ couples whose names are chosen at random from Santos's county will produce information from which he can make a valid conclusion.
The $30$ couples married most recently in  Santos's county may not be representative of the entire population of couples married in the county.
The valid method:  Sort a list of couples married in his county into a random order, then ask the first $30$ couples on the list.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: The library is trying to decide which book to feature in next month's young adult book club, *Salt to the Sea* or *The Sun is Also a Star*.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow the library to make a valid conclusion about which book the young adults who use their library would prefer?**

options.content: Ask $120$ randomly selected people from a list of all young adults registered to the library.
Ask $120$ randomly selected people from a list of all people registered to the library.

hints.content: Both groups are random samples, so the library could generalize the results from each sample to the population from which they came.  Which population is the library interested in?
The library wants to pick a book for the young adults book club, and they are specifically wanting to make a conclusion about the young adults who use their library.
The valid method:  Ask $120$ randomly selected people from a list of all young adults registered to the library.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Ron intends to survey spectators at the Quidditch World Championship to find out which team has the most spectators' support.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow Ron to make a valid conclusion about which team has the most spectators' support?**

options.content: Put the names of all of the spectators who speak the same language as Ron does into a cauldron, mix them up, draw out $75$ names, and survey those spectators.
Put the names of all of the spectators into a cauldron, mix them up, draw out $75$ names, and survey those spectators.

hints.content: Both groups are random samples, so Ron could generalize the results from each sample to the population from which they came.  Which population is Ron interested in?
Ron wants to make conclusions about all spectators at the Quidditch World Championship, not just about the spectators who speak the same language he does.
The valid method:  Put the names of all of the spectators into a cauldron, mix them up, draw out $75$ names, and survey those spectators.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: The drama teacher wants to know whether more families of students at the school would attend a musical or a comedy.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow the drama teacher to make a valid conclusion about which genre of performance more families would attend?**

options.content: Assign a number to each family, use a computer program to select $20$ random numbers between $1$ and the total number of families,  and ask the families selected.

For each letter of the alphabet, assign a number to each family whose last name begins with that letter, use a computer program to select a random number between $1$ and the total number of families whose last name begins with that letter,  and ask the family selected.

hints.content: Both methods are random, but only one method gives the drama teacher an equal chance of selecting each family.

If the drama teacher selects one family whose last names begin with each letter, then the teacher is more likely to choose families whose last names begin with uncommon letters than to choose other families.
The valid method:  Assign a number to each family, use a computer program to select $20$ random numbers between $1$ and the total number of families,  and ask the families selected.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: The cafeteria director at Great Minds School wants to know what percent of the students would choose vegetarian entrees if they were available.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow the director to make a valid conclusion about the percentage of students who would choose vegetarian entrees?**

options.content: Sort a list of the students into a random order, then ask the first $35$ students on the list.
Ask the first $35$ students in line for the cafeteria.

hints.content: Asking $35$ students whose names are chosen at random will produce information from which the director can make a valid conclusion.
The first $35$ students in the cafeteria line may not be representative of the entire population of students at Great Minds School.
The valid method:  Sort a list of the students into a random order, then ask the first $35$ students on the list.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results

question.content: Nayara wants to know the percentage of each grade level of students at her school who drive to school. She has $4$ grade levels in her school.     **Which of the following survey methods will allow Nayara to make a valid conclusion about what percentage of each grade level of students drive to school?**

options.content: Randomly select $48$ students who drive to school and ask them their grade level.
Randomly select $12$ students from each grade level and ask whether they drive to school.

hints.content: Both methods are random, but only one method gives Nayara an equal chance of surveying every student within a grade level.
If Nayara selects students who drive to school, she has no chance of selecting students in the grade level who do not drive to school.
The valid method:  Randomly select $12$ students from each grade level and ask whether they drive to school.

item.problemType: Choose a method for obtaining valid results
